texts.shortText: The largest species of tern. Body with pale grey upper parts and white underparts, a black crest on the head covers eye. Black tips to underwings visible in flight. Long, bright-red, dagger-like bill with black tip. Eyes reddish brown, legs and feet black with orange soles.
Total length 47-54 cm, wingspan 130-145 cm, mass 690 g, sexes alike, but female slightly smaller than male.

Global: Widespread across Europe, North America, Asia, Africa and Australasia, but absent from South America.

Local/Regional: Along the coast across region, more rarely inland.

Found mostly along the coast mostly in sheltered bays, estuaries and lagoons. Usually solitary or in family groups, congregating in larger groups when roosting. Flight leisurely and gull like with deep, powerful wing beats.

Forages in clear, shallow water, hovering 3-20 m above the water with bill pointed downwards and then flexing wings inwards and plunging into the water, feeds during the day, mostly in morning.
Feeds almost entirely small fish of <20 cm which are swallowed head first while on the wing. Most common prey species in Western Cape are mullet.

Monogamous, with pair bond persisting from year to year and solitary of colonial nesters. Nest a shallow scrape on the ground, usually lined with dried vegetation, defend a territory around the nest site. In Western Cape mostly lay in October-January. Eggs sandy to greenish-cream, blotched with brown or purplish spots. Incubation 22-24 days, fledge at 30-35 days but depending on parental feeding up to 8 months.
The bright red, blacked-tipped bill and large size are distinctive.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 352).
